description.narrative: Vietnam is the second-largest producer of coffee in the world and the largest exporter ofRobusta beans. Coffee is the second most important agricultural commodity in Vietnam, afterrice, contributing USD 3 billion to the Vietnamese economy, or roughly two to four percent of itsGDP. It also accounts for around 40% of global Robusta production and nearly 60 percent ofglobal Robusta exports. Around 90% of VietNam’s coffee production comes from the CentralHighlands- the agricultural hub of the country.Vietnamese farmers typically reach yields of more than 3.5 tonnes per hectare, compared to 0.8tonnes per hectare in Thailand, 0.5 tonnes per hectare in Indonesia, and only 0.4 tonnes perhectare in Lao PDR. While this growth has made a significant contribution to the Vietnameseeconomy, it has not come without costs. In fact, maintaining such high levels of productivity hasgenerated a series of environmental challenges, including deforestation and ecosystemdegradation.Climate change poses another threat to the country’s coffee sector and poor farming techniquescause environmental degradation and water pollution. Also, the agriculture sector ischaracterized by a stagnant and low share of value adding in the value chain, due to high inputcosts, variation in production and incorporation of new services. Therefore our project will focuson two important ICSR issues in the coffee value chain in Vietnam:1. The unequal value distribution in the supply chain leading to a weak economic positionof coffee farmers.2. Sustainability (climate change and environment).To mitigate the CSR risks t in the coffee chain in Vietnam , koffieDirect will make local coffee farmers co-owner of KoffieDirect.By using new technologies Koffiedirect will integrate farmers in thevalue chain. In practice, this means that the farmers will get access to the GREENcoffee app(which contains personalised and dynamic advice based on Good Agricultural Practices). Theapp will connect farmers with Blockchain technology to generate transparency on thetransactions with the buyers. By giving farmers access to the existing GREENcoffee app, wthe farmers will get acceess to environmental friendly agricultural practices enabling them toreduce inputs without jeopardising yields .
